articles.headline: Glenn Britt to Retire as Time Warner Cable Chief
articles.snippet: Mr. Britt, 64, will be succeeded by Robert Marcus, who at 48 represents generational change both for the company and the industry.
articles.abstract: Mr. Britt, 64, will be succeeded by Robert Marcus, who at 48 represents generational change both for the company and the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Glenn A. Britt got started in the nascent cable television business in the 1970s, no one knew whether people would pay a monthly fee for something that was already available free through an antenna. Nowadays, most Americans do pay companies like Mr. Britt’s Time Warner Cable, not just for television, but for broadband Internet, too.

articles.headline: Intersection of Fraud and Traffic Violations
articles.snippet: Results of a study could indicate that people who are willing to violate one set of social norms are more likely to be willing to violate far more serious ones.
articles.abstract: Results of a study could indicate that people who are willing to violate one set of social norms are more likely to be willing to violate far more serious ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the chief executive likes to drive too fast, watch out. He may be more likely to commit fraud.

articles.headline: Halliburton Pleads Guilty to Destroying Evidence After Gulf Spill
articles.snippet: The oil services company will pay the maximum allowable fine and be subject to three years of probation, the Justice Department said.
articles.abstract: The oil services company will pay the maximum allowable fine and be subject to three years of probation, the Justice Department said.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Halliburton has agreed to plead guilty to destruction of critical evidence after the Gulf of Mexico oil spill in 2010, the Justice Department announced on Thursday.

articles.headline: A Relentless Prosecutor’s Crowning Case
articles.snippet: The charges against SAC Capital Advisors are the culmination of an investigation of nearly a decade and are a rare and bold step.
articles.abstract: The charges against SAC Capital Advisors are the culmination of an investigation of nearly a decade and are a rare and bold step.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent years, Preet Bharara has prosecuted members of the powerful Latin Kings gang in Newburgh, N.Y., exposed corrupt state politicians and convicted terrorists.

articles.headline: Wall Street’s Exposure to Hacking Laid Bare
articles.snippet: Five people were accused of hacking into the servers of major companies and Nasdaq, showing the vulnerability of some computer systems.
articles.abstract: Five people were accused of hacking into the servers of major companies and Nasdaq, showing the vulnerability of some computer systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: The indictment on Thursday of a long-running hacking ring is kindling fears that rogue programmers are going beyond theft and developing the capacity to wreak havoc on the broader financial system.

articles.headline: Chinese Search for Infant Formula Goes Global
articles.snippet: Fueled by distrust of domestic brands, Chinese parents are buying up foreign-made infant milk powder, and that has led to shortages in at least a half-dozen other countries.
articles.abstract: Fueled by distrust of domestic brands, Chinese parents are buying up foreign-made infant milk powder, and that has led to shortages in at least a half-dozen other countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The group of 40 mainland Chinese tourists made all the requisite shopping purchases on a recent trip to Europe: silk scarves, Swiss watches, Louis Vuitton handbags.

articles.headline: SAC Case Threatens a Wall St. Cash Cow
articles.snippet: What happens on Wall Street now that SAC Capital Advisors has been accused?
articles.abstract: What happens on Wall Street now that SAC Capital Advisors has been accused?
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street now has to contemplate life without SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund that manages billions of dollars.

articles.headline: In Tug of War Over New Fed Leader, Some Gender Undertones
articles.snippet: The choice of who will succeed Ben S. Bernanke to lead the Federal Reserve is roiling Washington as it revives questions about the dearth of women in its top economic policy positions.
articles.abstract: The choice of who will succeed Ben S. Bernanke to lead the Federal Reserve is roiling Washington as it revives questions about the dearth of women in its top economic policy positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s choice of a replacement for the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, is coming down to a battle between the California girls and the Rubin boys.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Annie Lowrey

articles.headline: Roberts’s Picks Reshaping Secret Surveillance Court
articles.snippet: As Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has filled the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court with Republican appointees, critics have voiced concern about their deference to the government on spying.
articles.abstract: As Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has filled the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court with Republican appointees, critics have voiced concern about their deference to the government on spying.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The recent leaks about government spying programs have focused attention on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court and its role in deciding how intrusive the  government can be in the name of national security. Less mentioned has been the person who has been quietly reshaping the secret court: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.

articles.headline: Science Lowers Shattering Risk at Home Plate
articles.snippet: In an unusual partnership with Major League Baseball, Forest Service scientists looked deep into maple’s core to find why it was so brittle, and how it could be made less so.
articles.abstract: In an unusual partnership with Major League Baseball, Forest Service scientists looked deep into maple’s core to find why it was so brittle, and how it could be made less so.
articles.lead_paragraph: Welington Castillo smashed a double for the Chicago Cubs late in a game in the 2010 season, his bat exploding on impact with the ball. A long shard of wood flew at a teammate, Tyler Colvin, sprinting home from third base, impaling him a few inches from his heart. Though Colvin scored, his season was over.

articles.headline: Egypt Military Flexes Muscle Against Morsi Amid Rallies
articles.snippet: After announcing that Mohamed Morsi could face serious criminal charges, the Egyptian military orchestrated a display of military power in an effort to crack down on demonstrators.
articles.abstract: After announcing that Mohamed Morsi could face serious criminal charges, the Egyptian military orchestrated a display of military power in an effort to crack down on demonstrators.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian military stepped up its campaign against the Muslim Brotherhood on Friday, as officials announced the possibility of serious criminal charges carrying the death penalty against the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, and hopes faded for any sort of political accommodation with the Islamist group.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Chipping Away at the Smartphone Leaders
articles.snippet: The competition in high-end cellphones is stirring, and consumers are giving a new look to brands they once ignored, a factor Samsung acknowledged in its latest earnings report.
articles.abstract: The competition in high-end cellphones is stirring, and consumers are giving a new look to brands they once ignored, a factor Samsung acknowledged in its latest earnings report.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — As Samsung Electronics and Apple continue to slug it out across the globe for domination of the smartphone market, the South Korean maker continues to edge out the California company.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Says Importers Must Audit Food Safety
articles.snippet: If the rules are made final, they would shift the responsibility for ensuring that food is safe from the F.D.A. to companies like Walmart and Cargill.
articles.abstract: If the rules are made final, they would shift the responsibility for ensuring that food is safe from the F.D.A. to companies like Walmart and Cargill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than two years after Congress passed a landmark law meant to prevent the importation of contaminated food that sickens Americans, the Food and Drug Administration proposed rules on Friday that for the first time put the main onus on companies to police the food they import.

articles.headline: A Start-Up Aims to Bring Financial Planning to the Masses
articles.snippet: If Alexa von Tobel has her way, financial advice will be as widely available — and affordable — as any other popular consumer product or service.
articles.abstract: If Alexa von Tobel has her way, financial advice will be as widely available — and affordable — as any other popular consumer product or service.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s an unfortunate fact: the people who are most in need of honest financial advice often cannot afford it, or they don’t realize that their so-called adviser isn’t an adviser at all, but a salesman.
